Award.AwardTitle: Parametric Estimation of Stochastic Differential Equations under Indirect Observability
Award.AbstractNarration:
We will develop mathematical formalism for estimating fluctuations in parameters in stochastic parametrizations due to changes in the large-scale forcing (forcing applied to the large-scale structures). The forcing will be chosen to mimic the global warming scenario. Therefore, the proposed research will elucidate the validity of stochastic parametrizations estimated from the present-day climate for other climatological conditions. We propose a novel technique for estimating parameters in stochastic parametrizations of small-scale processes from the data of the large (resolved) scales alone. In the course of the proposed research we will develop rigorous mathematical foundation for accurate estimation of parameters from the time-series of large scale.

Stochastic models (also known as stochastic parametrizations) play an important role in Global Circulation Models of the atmosphere and ocean. In particular, stochastic models represent small-scale physical processes which cannot be sufficiently accurately resolved by modern numerical methods. Typically, parameters in these stochastic models are estimated from the present-day climate. The key question is how stochastic parametrizations will change in response to global climate change. In particular, estimation of stochastic models from time-series of large-scale structures can fail if the time-step of observation is too small. This is due to the fundamental differences between the trajectories of stochastic models and observed data. We will develop mathematical techniques to overcome this problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the proposed research is to investigate the sub-sampling issue (dependence on the observational time-step) in estimation of parameters in stochastic models arising from numerical/observational data. The main goal of such models is to reproduce the behavior of the underlying physical process (e.g. weather, financial markets, etc.) in statistical sense (i.e. on average). Therefore, accurate estimation of parameters from past observations becomes an important practical task. However, in many practical applications the data is not exact (i.e. only approximately agrees with the model proposed for estimation); we refer to such situation as indirect observability. Indirect observability arises, for example, when some physical processes cannot be observed directly (e.g. small scales in the atmosphere, volatility of the financial market); in this case an approximating process can be constructed and used to estimate parameters of the model. The main goal of this work is analyze parameter estimation errors due to the indirect observability and to develop optimal sampling criteria for collecting observational data.

Several papers have been published where we analyzed parameter estimation under indirect observability. We considered estimation of Gaussian and non-Gaussian models. Particular emphasis was given to stochastic differential equations driven by Brownian motion. We also presented several numerical examples illustrating that parametric estimation under indirect observability can potentially lead to large errors in parameter estimation (and thus wrong models). To minimize these errors we derived optimal criteria (for the sampling time-step of observational data and the number of sampled points) which optimize the estimation procedure. We also developed a novel algorithm which can be used for testing how sampling time-step affects estimation errors in models estimated from observational data. These results have been published in scientific papers and presented at several conferences.

This research was the main topic for dissertations of three Ph.D. students in the department of mathematics.
